discussion.p:
In [cmplx.over] and [cmath.syn], when talking about "sufficient additional overloads", we use the phrase "effectively cast", but that is not a defined term.
A hostile interpretation could read "reinterpret_cast" here.
Likely we mean "apply floating-point promotions, floating-integral conversions, and floating-point conversions", but that should be spelled out somewhere, e.g. in the library definitions section.
(Source: Editorial issue #1248)

I decided to use the form "converted" and to refer to for and , because those conversions can all be done implicitly. This also holds for the pow specification p3, because the described conversions of complex<T> to complex<U> involve only the need of non-explicit constructors.

resolution.p: This wording is relative to N4810.

blockquote.p:
-2- The additional overloads shall be sufficient to ensure:
(2.1) — If the argument has type long double, then it is effectively castconverted () to complex<long double>.
(2.2) — Otherwise, if the argument has type double or an integer type, then it is effectively castconverted () to complex<double>.
(2.3) — Otherwise, if the argument has type float, then it is effectively castconverted () to complex<float>.
-3 Function template pow shall have additional overloads sufficient to ensure, for a call with at least one argument of type complex<T>:
(3.1) — If either argument has type complex<long double> or type long double, then both arguments are effectively castconverted () to complex<long double>.
(3.2) — Otherwise, if either argument has type complex<double>, double, or an integer type, then both arguments are effectively castconverted () to complex<double>.
(3.3) — Otherwise, if either argument has type complex<float> or float, then both arguments are effectively castconverted () to complex<float>.

-2- For each set of overloaded functions within <cmath>, with the exception of abs, there shall be additional overloads sufficient to ensure:
If any argument of arithmetic type corresponding to a double parameter has type long double, then all arguments of arithmetic type () corresponding to double parameters are effectively castconverted () to long double.
Otherwise, if any argument of arithmetic type corresponding to a double parameter has type double or an integer type, then all arguments of arithmetic type corresponding to double parameters are effectively castconverted () to double.
Otherwise, all arguments of arithmetic type corresponding to double parameters have type float.
